article.headline: Arkansas 83, Lipscomb 54
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Arkansas coach Stan Heath created a nonconference schedule hoping it would instill confidence among his players. It seems to be working. Feeding off Jonathon Modica's team-high 16 points, Arkansas matched its best start since its 1994 national championship season with an 83-54 victory over Lipscomb on Monday. "I'm sure we're not playing the same schedulle as the teams from '94 or '95, but we're real happy with our start," Heath said. "We're probably further ahead than everybody thought we'd be at this point. We're winning the games we're supposed to win." The Razorbacks (9-1), who had four players in double figures, were on the Bisons early. Arkansas shut down Lipscomb's efforts to work the ball inside -- limiting the visitors to 33 percent shooting in the first half -- and produced its own points in the paint in taking a 48-24 halftime lead. The Bisons (6-2) were the latest team to have trouble scoring against an Arkansas defense that leads the SEC in field goal percentage defense and is limiting opponents to 36 percent shooting. But the night belonged to Modica, who led the team in scoring last year before falling into an offensive malaise for much of this season. He shot 6-of-9 from the floor and made three 3-pointers after entering the game from the bench. "He's back," Heath said. "He's got confidence and he is playing with a swagger. Sometimes you have to take a step back to take two steps forward. That's what I think we have seen with him." Lipscomb didn't have a chance once the Razorbacks shut down Brian Fisk, who had 12 of Lipscomb's first 14 points. Arkansas turned a 12-7 disadvantage into a 23-15 lead -- aided by a Modica 3-pointer, a 10-second violation on the Bisons, and a three-point play off a Ronnie Brewer to Modica alley-oop. "We started out a little slow," Brewer said. "They were hitting a few shots, but we stuck to what we were doing. We started executing and took control. We definitely wanted to get (Modica) going." The lead hit 20 when Olu Famutimi connected on a 3-pointer with less than two minutes remaining before halftime. No Arkansas starter played more than 25 minutes. Fisk, who finished with 18 points, made five of his first six shots but was 2-for-10 the rest of the game. James Poindexter added 12 points for Lipscomb. Darian Townes, a 6-10 center, worked effectively against the Bisons, who had no player taller than 6-9. The freshman scored 15 points, as did Famutimi. Brewer finished with 13. "They are very big and deep," Lipscomb coach Scott Sanderson said. "Their size and strength wore us down." As the Razorbacks clamped down on defense, the Arkansas' offense heated up. Brewer dunked the ball off a spin move to push the Razorbacks' lead to 35-21 with 4½ minutes left in the first half and the lead was 42-22 after the Famutimi 3. Arkansas' 1994 national championship team opened its season 10-0 and the Razorbacks were 9-1 through the first 10 games of the 1995 season, when they were the national runners-up. "We're always happy with wins," Heath said. "This is valuable time for the confidence factor."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
